item.description:
CAPITALISM ON TRIAL:
A CONFERENCE IN HONOR OF THOMAS E. WEISSKOPF
Political Economy Research Institute
University of Massachusetts-Amherst
September 30 – October 1, 2011
Friday, September 30


Breakfast
8:00 a.m. – 9:00 a.m.


Session 1: Reflections on Thomas Weisskopf’s Contributions to Political Economy
9:00 a.m. – 10:30 a.m.
Samuel Bowles, Economics, UMass Amherst, “Three’s a Crowd: My Dinner Party with Karl,
Leon, and Maynard”
Robert Pollin, Economics and PERI, UMass Amherst, “Theses on Weisskopf”
Discussant: Diane Flaherty, Economics, UMass Amherst


Session 2: Issues in Developing Economies
10:45 a.m. – 12:45 p.m.
Shahrukh Rafi Khan, Economics, Mt. Holyoke College, “The Military and Economic
Development: The Case of Pakistan.”
Minqi Li, Economics, University of Utah, “Socialism: the 20th Century and the 21st Century.”
Mark Weisbrot, Center for Economic and Policy Research, “Changing Relations Between
Developed and Developing Countries.”
Discussant: Jim Boyce, Economics and PERI, UMass Amherst


Lunch
12:45 p.m. -2:15 p.m.


Session 3: Power Dynamics in Capitalism
2:15 p.m. – 3:45 p.m.
Nancy Folbre, Economics, UMass Amherst, “The Rise and Decline of Patriarchal Capitalism.”
Arthur MacEwan, Economics, UMass Boston, “The Wealth-Power Connection.”
Discussant: Andy Zimbalist, Economics, Smith College


Session 4: Trends in U.S. Labor Markets
4:00 p.m. – 5:30 p.m.
Michael Reich, Economics, U. of California-Berkeley, “Segmented Labor Markets: The 1970s
and Now.”
Juliet Schor, Economics and Sociology, Boston College, “New Directions in Hours, Employment
and Productivity: The Emergence of Alternative Lifestyles.”
Discussant: Lee Badgett, Economics, UMass-Amherst
